Stopping a bad and illegal idea that was only possible with the impetus and initiative from his own administration is not a great achievement, but the apprehension how foolish one was. Nevertheless, a good day.

Change: -5 Reasoning: There is a lot of speculation that Israel is headed towards the fourth round of elections.

The below article shows that it requires US support and this is unequivocal at this moment. I do think that Trump may just allow this to happen if he feels he won't be re-elected, but I expect/hope that the whispers will start well in advance of any action. https://www.jpost.com/israel-news/netanyahu-us-has-kept-me-from-annexing-west-bank-settlements-638191

Complicated. Raising for awhile. https://www.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/why-august-is-critical-for-west-bank-annexation-analysis-637497
Would Trump say go ahead? The World would break out in chaos. Probably does not want to deal with that on too of everything else. On the other hand he might enjoy the focus being elsewhere than the US. Waiting till end of August to decide more.

Confidence slightly lowered as US seemingly is not interested in progressing this right now.  Deadline is prior to August from my understanding and Netanyahu is looking like he can't get this done with his own issues to worry about.
Dropping due to timing of elections and investigations.

Change: -2 Reasoning: Bibi explained the delay by saying that they are "waiting on Washington" which is a terrible place to be because Washington has no time or energy to think about Israel right now and it looks unlikely that Washington will put thought into it in time to give the Kenesset enough time to establish what they think of the specific annexation plan and debate before the November elections.

We are not into August and as we come to summer the chances begin to dwindle. COVID has not gone away and more likely will begin to pick up as we get into winter. Though the Ultra-Orthodox wants to Annex however they are also the larger group getting sick. Netanyahu needs to support them first health-wise. EU countries have all come forward to say it is outright illegal and could put financial and economic pressure on Isreal, and during COVID that aggravates an economic situation even more. It will go down farther cat the end of August. Once we hit the Jewish hi holidays and the election season in the US, it would put the Annex discussion in a holding pattern until the new cards are placed. The recent Lebanon explosion also puts focus on the need to support poorer Arab communities and the destruction there could highlight of the poverty Netenyahu has placed on the  Palestinians, creating a perception of opress.
Annexation will cause too many problems for Netanyahu who already won the election. Now, he can proceed to break his promises while continuing to rant about it.
Lowering to the crowd for now. I can find no move to present a bill for this. Netanyahu may want another election first in hopes of throwing off his coalition partner.
It seems like Netanyahu would want to get an ok before Trump leaves office; if he does. There is a lot of pushback and his coalition with Gantz is rocky so lowering.
They have the votes and they want to do it, so it will likely happen.
With another increase in popular opposition to Netanyahoo's government the chances go lever lower

My current thinking on this is that Bibi needs a good opportunity for this to happen. Such an opportunity will emerge if 1) Coronavirus dominates less media attention so that he can focus governing energy on annexation, 2) Trump lets him deviate from the US Peace plan or 3) Trump wins re-election. The problem is that Bibi needs one of these just to start the conversation and release the sovereignty plan at which point a lot of Israeli's will have input. I still think there is a sort of "soft annexation" that he might try to push through in September assuming covid numbers stabilize. It is hard to be confident because it is a dynamic situation and I believe Bibi is looking for the right moment to make a move on annexation.

I'm revisiting this question for the first time since I made an original prediction (should have revised earlier). Swinging big in the opposite direction, a lot of information garnered from this article: https://www.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/if-netanyahu-opts-for-elections-will-west-bank-annexation-be-lost-636158 When I originally forecast this, I don't believe I put enough stock on what should have been the biggest prior - this has never happened. I also didn't include that this might not even be popular with Israel's own people. Also - given current state of affairs, if this would mean the end of the coalition government, that would be a lot to sacrifice politically right now. Really I think I should have had the base rate on this should have been much lower on this to begin with, with slight upticks because of votes in lower arenas being pushed. But based on current information, it seems like there would have to be a lot of momentum. With time already ticking as well on the summer, soon the US will be very distracted with elections, potentially heading this towards even worse timing.
Too high but key is Netanyahu status with the electorate.  https://www.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/if-netanyahu-opts-for-elections-will-west-bank-annexation-be-lost-636158
I know, I'm a born and raised Israeli, living her most of my life
Change (-10): The lack of an announcement by Bibi is foreboding at this point, as well as the chatter that he is too tied up with the Coronavirus pandemic.

Falling below the odds this happens at this moment, for the following reasons from the below source: - Meanwhile, Arab opposition to the plan has united with European condemnation to underline the costs of the ambition: an Emirati diplomat warned in a Hebrew newspaper that it would endanger Israel’s growing ties with Gulf states, and Germany’s foreign minister warned that the EU would see the move as a grave violation of international law. “Netanyahu triggered the perfect storm — a totally opposed Arab response, a totally opposed European response and more than hesitant American response,” said a senior Arab diplomat, adding that both the Russians and the Chinese also made their opposition clear. That raised the stakes considerably for Mr Netanyahu. “Nobody is going to approve of this, say this is a great move — instead, he would have pay a heavy price in terms of his international credibility without necessarily achieving much.” This week, the EU put teeth to its objections by approving millions of euros in grants to Palestinians wanting to build public infrastructure on the land that Mr Netanyahu seeks to annex, called Area C, which makes up 60 per cent of the West Bank and is still administered entirely by the Israeli army. - Mainstream Israeli society does not particularly care either: polls have repeatedly shown that voters place the threat of coronavirus to their health and to the economy ahead of any other concern. A recent poll by the Israel Democracy Institute showed about a third saying they were undecided on annexation, and a quarter opposed. The quarter who supported the move dropped by half when told that annexation would require Israel to sanction the creation of a Palestinian state, something the US plan theoretically envisions. Source: https://www.ft.com/content/4e091f28-d5df-4e3b-831a-f7704266b4de

Even if I don't think it would be an especially smart decision right now, it seems USA and ISR are set to give it a try and then leave it unenforced. UN will be blocked, so international confrontation is not to be feared at the moment. It seems to go together well with Kushner and Netanyahu's perceived plan to dismount the Security Council in questions like these. Irritations among and protests from the Arabic world will be huge, but this will not stop them.

Apparently Trump Administration has to make an announcement first after details worked out. Look for that. https://gvwire.com/2020/07/01/west-bank-annexation-will-happen-after-trump-statement-likud-minister-says/

A cornerstone of Netanyahu’s election promises was to proceed with annexation of West Bank territory. Annexation is illegal under International law and this proposed action has created opprobrium from International actors with one exception that is the Trump administration.
The proposed date of July 1st, 2020 has passed.
Israel now has a coalition government that has created a degree of stability, politically, for the moment.
The Trump Presidency provides the best opportunity for Israel to act and it will only act with the permission of the White House, who are preoccupied with Covid-19, the economy and the upcoming Presidential elections.
Russia, a major player in the region, after its annexation of the Crimea would not interfere.
The Gulf States appear to be disinterested.
Annexation could/would provide further disruption in the Middle East and raise the profile of Palestinians.
+/- 30% of Israelis oppose annexation.
Without collecting the opprobrium of the International theatre and considering 400,000 Israelis already settled in the West Bank and thereby creating a ‘creeping sovereignty’ there would only be political advantage to a formal annexation.
However, due to Covid-19 and criticism of Netanyahu over the handling of the pandemic plus the effect on the country’s economy have redirected attention away from annexation, for the time being.
I propose that the Knesset will not pass a bill to annex and/or apply sovereignty before January 1, 2021 https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-53139808  https://fas.org/sgp/crs/mideast/R46433.pdf  https://www.npr.org/2020/07/01/885728003/delay-appears-likely-in-israels-plans-to-annex-parts-of-west-bank  https://english.alarabiya.net/en/News/middle-east/2020/06/09/Israel-must-face-consequences-over-planned-West-Bank-annexations-says-Palestinian-PM  https://moderndiplomacy.eu/2020/07/01/netanyahus-plan-to-annex-west-bank-old-and-new-problems/  https://www.un.org/press/en/2020/sc14225.doc.htm  https://www.jpost.com/israel-news/politics-and-diplomacy/government-vote-could-make-west-bank-annexation-more-difficult-634760  https://www.aa.com.tr/en/middle-east/israel-to-initially-annex-3-settlement-blocs-in-w-bank/1871903  https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jun/09/what-would-israel-annexing-the-west-bank-mean  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-53139817  https://www.jpost.com/breaking-news/netanyahu-annexation-map-not-ready-yet-dont-know-blue-and-white-position-631551  https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-52756427  https://www.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/right-pushes-for-sunday-west-bank-annexation-vote-at-ministerial-committee-635045  https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/middle_east/israels-west-bank-annexation-stalls-for-now-amid-pandemic-and-political-distractions/2020/07/16/31b7c2c8-c764-11ea-a825-8722004e4150_story.html

I don't know a lot about Isreal politics making this a good opportunity to learn some, but quick reading seems to suggest: 1. Netanyahu made this a part of his reelection campaign, meaning that he would probably like to do something and appease the right.
2. If they really do want US approval here, there's potentially limited time before Trump leaves office putting a time limit on this.
3. The question reads "will any" portion be annexed. It seems like there are many bodies at play here trying to make that happen.https://www.jpost.com/arab-israeli-conflict/right-pushes-for-sunday-west-bank-annexation-vote-at-ministerial-committee-635045 Big reasons this wouldn't happen:
1. This has not happened in history, suggesting that should be our prior.
2. This won't be popular with the rest of the world, suggesting momentum to overcome.
3. Politics are messy. Anytime you have to get a majority to agree can be very difficult. https://www.jpost.com/israel-news/politics-and-diplomacy/government-vote-could-make-west-bank-annexation-more-difficult-634760
4. The US is in a messy political situation, and they never give approval Seems like if this is going to happen, it needs momentum ASAP and then it should start to drop off.

Distraction technique, internationally messy, not exactly popular within Israel, etc. The fact that the international community are against it isn't a massive safeguard, though. Actually acting on their words seems like a politically bad move, I think. However, efforts to annex the West Bank have been continuous, and this is currently a good opportunity to cement their occupation there. I tentatively think it's more likely than not, but could easily be swayed.

I will still leave high as Netanyahu will need to do at least a symbolic three block area to please some of his supporters.

Increasing bet from "one in four" to "one in three" that it WON'T happen.  I doubt he cares for actual annexation to happen, and I doubt a true annexation will occur, but the bet call's only for whether a Bill will be Passed to be a winner.  I still think he'll play the brinkmanship card... and a bill will go through. He gets the cred he wants with the hardliners and can still equivocate later and blame many factors.  A perfect spot to be in for a guy like him.

Dropping markedly. Currently lacking support of Trump and settlers (who want it all, not just a piece). Still could happen but believe possibility will decrease with time...

Andoulou: "Netanyahu might cite the Palestinian, Arab and international opposition and lack of an agreement with the US administration on the annexation map as an excuse to postpone the move," Abu Nassar said. "In this scenario, [Netanyahu] will bet on time. He will keep the annexation on the table, but without setting a specific date for it," he said. "Netanyahu, however, might put the annexation into action at any time, most probably before US presidential elections in November."

Stating the obvious, it's all quite complicated. At first glance this seemed more likely than 60%, especially with limited time with Trump in office. But there is a lot of international opposition: https://www.economist.com/middle-east-and-africa/2020/06/27/israel-weighs-the-future-of-the-west-bank  I am doubtful annexation is actually that important to Netanyahu beyond the conversation/propaganda/distractions it enables, and there is a lot of geopolitical calculus to be done. That said, passing a bill may be necessary to create the national narrative he desires.
Even though priority are others, israel rarely slows down facing protests from outside

Change (+7) Reasoning: While there remains a lot of uncertainty around this question due to the issue of there not being a released map or a vote count of who is in favor of annexation the evidence out there indicates that a) Bibi is moving forward with a bill that will annex part of Palestine, b) he has the votes (although this will be uncertain until the plan is released), and c) there is not much that can divert the vote. a) Bibi is moving forward. http://click1.crm.foreignpolicy.com/xhcrrmqcqgrtdddptpgmstnqyvtmmncpspdcvsbvcdbvr_xrbdhbgcdgtdrchrdgcgg.html  b) He has the votes (from the Washington Post https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/nothing-is-clear-july-is-nearly-here--will-israel-move-to-annex-much-of-the-west-bank/2020/06/30/2172dfca-ba43-11ea-97c1-6cf116ffe26c_story.html): "Netanyahu, who is believed to have the votes to enact annexation without the support of the Gantz’s faction, responded that it was not his partner’s decision to make." It is hard to get evidence that is thinner than a one-sentence rumor but it is all I have to go on. Additionally, it makes sense. If you consider all parties to the right of Blue and White they do make up more than 50% of the Knesset.  c) It seem unlikely that anyone could sway him. Gantz has plummeted in the polls, so they are unlikely to walk out and call a new election and Bibi knows this. Gantz right now needs to wait out Bibi's term for political power. While there are a large number of democratic lawmakers opposed, few are willing to do more than finger wave. AOC's letter pledging to cut Israeli military aid does not have Biden's support or support of democrats outside of the progressive caucus. In the white house, Kushner would like this to go slow but Friedman just wants to give Israel what it wants so they are unlikely to issue a hard "no." There is talk of German sanctions (https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/opinion/annexation-palestine-netanyahu-calculus-200626104214700.html), which I will need to keep my eye on but that doesn't seem to have dissuaded Bibi yet. Many settlers are allegedly opposed but Bibi can circumvent this by making it a limited annexation with a promise for further gains once COVID has been dealt with. Overall the evidence contains a lot of uncertainty but points to a measure calling for limited annexation of parts of the West Bank. I would be it will be below the 30% threshold. Things to look for when the map comes out are: Joe Biden's response, the White House response, Gantz's response, Europe's response, and the settler communities' response. One the map is out my guess is it will take Gantz walking, Biden threatening to cut aid, a right-wing party defecting, or serious European sanctions to stop an annexation bill.

I am still of the belief Netenyahu will not annex. Annexing Palestine will create too much political backlash from the moderates, Europe and the UN. He may use that threat to gain a peace agreement, but I still am not convinced he will move foward. Any serach of the subjet is not only negtaive but very harsh crtisim on par with Russia's annexing, which is somethign Isreal does not want.

Finally jumping in.  I think a vote for annexation, of even a small number of settlements, if not of the whole West Bank and Jordan valley will be "voted" into life, for a YES win.  I also think Bibi will have control to let it stall or die, as far as implementation... depending on which way the wind blows. It's simply another tool to negotiate with. Thx to all who weighed in this afternoon. As with every time I bet on a Israel/Palestine question, I'm scared to death.

annexation could be the trigger for “igniting violence, rouse extremists and destabilising the entire Middle East and North African region” and would spell the end of normalization.    The “Peace to Prosperity” workshop, aimed at gathering and allocating $50bn investment to revive the Palestinian economy. As Palestinian Foreign Minister Riyad al-Maliki recently noted.Hamas head Ismail Haniya declared that it was “the duty of each free Palestinian citizen to rise up” against the annexation plans; Salah al-Bardawil, a senior Hamas official, called for the launch of “a popular revolution everywhere.” The only Arab state which has not diluted its words is Jordan, which shares a long border with Israel and which would bear the brunt of political instability and a potential refugee influx. Amman expressed its total rejection of the plan and King Abdullah has conducted last-minute in-person lobbying in the White House. Jordan, as one of only two Arab states with signed peace deals with Israel, has the tangible option of withdrawing its ambassador, an act which could send that 1994 treaty into a state of limbo.

Cleverly had told parliament in May that the UK would not support Israeli annexation of parts of the West Bank because it would make a “two-state solution” harder to achieve. The UK has not recognised Palestinian statehood.

Change: -10 Reasoning: There are a lot of variables involved all of which will come into play after the plan is released. These are: how will the security establishment react, how will the settlers and right-wing non-Likud parties react, and how will Biden react. All things to watch.
No sign of weakening in face of international condemnation; condemnation itself unlikely enough.

So - few to little consequences, both netanyahu and grantz have reasons to do it, there is US support (ish), and the question is quite open ended in that *any* territory would count. There currently isnt a plan but this looks like a fairly unique opportunity so why not?

My understanding is that the plan is in the works, Gantz is in no position or interest to fight it, and Netanyahu will want to go full steam ahead because this is a campaign promise. However, while bibi is full steam ahead it sounds like there is division both amongst settlers and the Trump cabinet about whether or not to proceed. Also, I am unsure if Likud has the votes, my understanding is that depending on the final plan support could be very split. In case you cannot tell Israeli political systems confuse me.

70% sounds about right. I'll see in a couple of days how this develops.

I am still saying it is not a high probability. The idea was completely rejected by the EU MPs and the UN is also pushing back. There will be no Israeli support in the EU and more discussions with Saudi Arabia and Iran and Egypt...

Although West Bank annexation has the overwhelming support of the Israeli Knesset, there are factors that belie the supposed peace it will bring to the region.   The Palestinians as a whole under Mahmoud Abbas have been extremely clear in position of Jared Kushners peace plan.  And that is a resounding vote against 30% or 3%.  Bill Clinton attempted to divide the lands in the 90’s with over 90% granted to forming a new Palestine state.  The Clinton Parameters addressed many of the concerns including demilitarizing the West Bank region. The mutual distrust and distaste for each on ethnic and religious  grounds led to a collapse of the most equilateral territorial agreement to date. Fast forwarding to the collapse of 3 American weapons and arms agreements, including the Iran nuclear deal, and consider the friction that will very likely stem from a unilateral Israel annexation, one must also consider the timing of the decision, future US/Israel relations,  the possibility of Iran opportunizing on declining world Israel sentiment, and the undesired Israeli citizenship that would be granted to Palestinians settled in the annexed region.  Netanyahu and Trump both seek homeruns, and though Netanyahu is in the twilight of his career and Trump the early morning, the Knesset vote will not be a landslide by any means, especially since the new Norwegian Law will rotate in more of Gantz loyal Blue and Whites.
After next year, Netenyahu has to deal with someone other than Trump, most likely, so they know if they want to do this, they have limited time to act.

Netanyahu wants it, but the current plans leave too much in Palestine and many Orthodox Jews want it all or nothing. Netanyahu would take advantage of it but the current black lives matter protests are almost an extension of the Arab uprising. People are tired of discrimination and hypocrisy in their governments. The multiple elections in Isreal speak to the internal fighting and views of progressive Jews vs Ultra-Orthodox, which live off welfare from the government. Netanyahu will need more support than he has now to annex, even a portion of it. Anti-annexation continues to grow and drown out the voices supporting annexing. People are also comparing this action to South Africa apartheid, which is not a position Isreal wants to be seen in. Isreal has become the bully and Gestapo over Arab communities. Even internal Mosad agents acknowledge past mistakes and recognize annex is not the right path forward. (Rise and Kill First)
